items.text: **East Orange** is a [[LINK|lang_en|City_(New_Jersey)|city]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Essex_County,_New_Jersey|Essex County]], [[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey|New Jersey]], United States. As of the [[LINK|lang_en|2010_United_States_Census|2010 United States Census]] the city's population was 64,270, [[CITE|186|http://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/DEC/10_DP/DPDP1/0600000US3401319390]] [[CITE|195|http://njelections.org/2011-legislative-districts/towns-district.pdf#page=14]] [[CITE|202|http://lwd.dol.state.nj.us/labor/lpa/census/2010/dp/dp1_ess/eastorange1.pdf]] reflecting a decline of 5,554 (−8.0%) from the 69,824 counted in the [[LINK|lang_en|2000_United_States_Census|2000 Census]], which had in turn declined by 3,728 (−5.1%) from the 73,552 counted in the [[LINK|lang_en|1990_United_States_Census|1990 Census]]. [[CITE|8|http://lwd.dol.state.nj.us/labor/lpa/census/2010/2010data/table7cm.xls]] The city was [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_municipalities_in_New_Jersey|the state's 20th most-populous municipality]] in 2010, after having been the state's 14th most-populous municipality in 2000. [[CITE|230|http://lwd.dol.state.nj.us/labor/lpa/census/2010/2010data/nj_tab1.xls]]

East Orange was originally incorporated as a [[LINK|lang_en|Township_(New_Jersey)|township]] by an act of the [[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey_Legislature|New Jersey Legislature]] on March 4, 1863, from portions of [[LINK|lang_en|Orange,_New_Jersey|Orange town]], and was reincorporated as a city on December 9, 1899, based on the results of a referendum held two days earlier. [[CITE|16|http://state.nj.us/dep/njgs/enviroed/oldpubs/bulletin67.pdf]]
Geography

According to the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Census_Bureau|United States Census Bureau]], the city had a total area of 3.924 square miles (10.164 km 2 ), all of it land. [[CITE|165|http://www2.census.gov/geo/docs/maps-data/data/gazetteer/county_sub_list_34.txt]]

East Orange shares borders with [[LINK|lang_en|Newark,_New_Jersey|Newark]] to the east and south, [[LINK|lang_en|South_Orange,_New_Jersey|South Orange]] to the southwest, [[LINK|lang_en|Orange,_New_Jersey|Orange]] to the west, and [[LINK|lang_en|Glen_Ridge,_New_Jersey|Glen Ridge]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Bloomfield,_New_Jersey|Bloomfield]] to the north. [[CITE|-1|https://web.archive.org/web/20120426060636/http://www.eastorange-nj.gov/PDFFiles/PEOPWard%20Boundaries.pdf]] [[CITE|25|http://global.mapit.mysociety.org/area/552314/touches.html]]

[[LINK|lang_en|Local_government_in_New_Jersey#Unincorporated_communities|Unincorporated communities]], localities and place names located partially or completely within the city include Ampere and Brick Church. [[CITE|30|http://state.nj.us/infobank/localnames.txt]]
Neighborhoods
East Orange is officially divided into five wards, but is also unofficially divided into a number of neighborhoods.

sentences.text: **[[LINK|lang_en|Ampere_(NJT_station)|Ampere]] ** : Anchored by the now defunct train station of the same name, The Ampere section was developed on land owned by Orange Water Works, after the construction of the Crocker Wheeler Company plant spurred development in the area. The station was named in honor of [[LINK|lang_en|André-Marie_Ampère|André-Marie Ampère]], a pioneer in electrodynamics and reconstructed as a new Renaissance Revival station in 1907 and 1908. Roughly bounded by [[LINK|lang_en|Bloomfield,_New_Jersey|Bloomfield]] to the North, Lawton Street & [[LINK|lang_en|Newark,_New_Jersey|Newark]] to the east, 4th Avenue to the south, and North Grove Street to the West.

**Greenwood (Teen Streets) [203]** : So named after Greenwood avenue and the "teen" streets that run through it. It is often grouped together with Ampere. This area was severely disturbed by the construction of [[LINK|lang_en|Interstate_280_(New_Jersey)|Interstate 280]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Garden_State_Parkway|Garden State Parkway]]. The Grove Street Station of the former [[LINK|lang_en|Delaware,_Lackawanna_and_Western_Railroad|DL & W]] Railroad was located here at Grove and Main Streets. Roughly bounded by 4th Avenue to the North, North 15th Street/ [[LINK|lang_en|Newark,_New_Jersey|Newark]] to the East, Eaton Place/ [[LINK|lang_en|NJ_Transit|NJ Transit]] [[LINK|lang_en|Morris_&_Essex_Lines|Morris & Essex Lines]], and North Grove Street to the West.

**Presidential Estates** : Recently designated due to the streets in this area being named after early presidents of the United States. There are many large houses situated on streets lined with very old, very large shade trees in this neighborhood that are characteristic of the northern section of the city. Roughly Bounded by Bloomfield to the North, [[LINK|lang_en|Montclair-Boonton_Line|Montclair-Boonton Line]] and North Grove Street to the East, Springdale Avenue to the South and the [[LINK|lang_en|Garden_State_Parkway|Garden State Parkway]] to the West.

**Elmwood** Located in the southeastern part of the city. Elmwood Park serves this section of the city, with 7 tennis courts on Rhode Island Avenue, a basketball court on the corner of Elmwood Avenue and Oak Street, a swimming pool with a pool house, a walking track, a baseball field, a softball field and a renovated field house. [[CITE|172|https://web.archive.org/web/20140916034007/http://www.eastorange-nj.gov/Departments/Recreation/ourparks.html]] The area holds one of the surviving Carnegie Libraries, the Elmwood Branch of the [[LINK|lang_en|East_Orange_Public_Library|East Orange Public Library]], opened in 1912. [[CITE|47|https://books.google.com/books?id=9SsrumYZXQ0C&pg=PA28]]

**Doddtown (Franklin)** : Named after John Dodd who founded and surveyed the area of the "Watsessing Plain". [[CITE|50|http://eohistory.info/EOTimeLine/1679.htm]] The former campus of [[LINK|lang_en|Upsala_College|Upsala College]] is located here. It was converted into the new [[LINK|lang_en|East_Orange_Campus_High_School|East Orange Campus High School]] on the east side of Prospect Street, and an adjacent new housing subdivision. Roughly bounded by [[LINK|lang_en|Bloomfield,_New_Jersey|Bloomfield]] to the North, the [[LINK|lang_en|Garden_State_Parkway|Garden State Parkway]] to the south, Park Avenue to the South and [[LINK|lang_en|Orange,_New_Jersey|Orange]] to the west.

items.text: Demographics
2010 Census

As of the [[LINK|lang_en|2010_United_States_Census|2010 United States Census]], there were 64,270 people, 24,945 households, and 14,742 families residing in the city. The [[LINK|lang_en|Population_density|population density]] was 16,377.1 per square mile (6,323.2/km 2 ). There were 28,803 housing units at an average density of 7,339.5 per square mile (2,833.8/km 2 ). The racial makeup of the city was 4.13% (2,657) [[LINK|lang_en|White_(U.S._Census)|White]], 88.51% (56,887) [[LINK|lang_en|Black_(U.S._Census)|Black or African American]], 0.39% (248) [[LINK|lang_en|Native_American_(U.S._Census)|Native American]], 0.72% (465) [[LINK|lang_en|Asian_(U.S._Census)|Asian]], 0.06% (38) [[LINK|lang_en|Pacific_Islander_(U.S._Census)|Pacific Islander]], 3.69% (2,370) from [[LINK|lang_en|Race_and_ethnicity_in_the_United_States_Census#Race|other races]], and 2.50% (1,605) from two or more races. [[LINK|lang_en|Hispanic_(U.S._Census)|Hispanic or Latino]] of any race were 7.93% (5,095) of the population. [[CITE|186|http://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/DEC/10_DP/DPDP1/0600000US3401319390]]

There were 24,945 households out of which 29.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 23.3% were married couples living together, 29.0% had a female householder with no husband present, and 40.9% were non-families.
35.8% of all households were made up of individuals, and 11.1% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.
The average household size was 2.53 and the average family size was 3.33. [[CITE|186|http://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/DEC/10_DP/DPDP1/0600000US3401319390]]
In the city, the population was spread out with 25.7% under the age of 18, 10.2% from 18 to 24, 27.8% from 25 to 44, 24.6% from 45 to 64, and 11.8% who were 65 years of age or older.
The median age was 35.0 years.
For every 100 females there were 81.2 males.
For every 100 females ages 18 and older there were 75.4 males.
[[CITE|186|http://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/DEC/10_DP/DPDP1/0600000US3401319390]]

The Census Bureau's 2006–2010 [[LINK|lang_en|American_Community_Survey|American Community Survey]] showed that (in 2010 [[LINK|lang_en|Inflation_adjustment|inflation-adjusted]] dollars) [[LINK|lang_en|Median_household_income|median household income]] was $40,358 (with a margin of error of +/− $1,873) and the median family income was $50,995 (+/− $2,877). Males had a median income of $38,642 (+/− $1,851) versus $39,843 (+/− $2,187) for females. The [[LINK|lang_en|Per_capita_income|per capita income]] for the city was $20,298 (+/− $746). About 17.8% of families and 21.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 32.5% of those under age 18 and 16.4% of those age 65 or over. [[CITE|110|http://state.nj.us/dca/home/2017mayors.pdf]]
2000 Census

As of the [[LINK|lang_en|2000_United_States_Census|2000 United States Census]] there were 69,824 people, 26,024 households, and 16,082 families residing in the city. The [[LINK|lang_en|Population_density|population density]] was 17,776.6 people per square mile (6,859.8/km 2 ). There were 28,485 housing units at an average density of 7,252.0 per square mile (2,798.5/km 2 ). The racial makeup of the city was 89.46% [[LINK|lang_en|African_American_(U.S._Census)|Black or African American]], 3.84% [[LINK|lang_en|White_(U.S._Census)|White]], 0.25% [[LINK|lang_en|Native_American_(U.S._Census)|Native American]], 0.43% [[LINK|lang_en|Asian_(U.S._Census)|Asian]], 0.07% [[LINK|lang_en|Pacific_Islander_(U.S._Census)|Pacific Islander]], 2.14% from [[LINK|lang_en|Race_(United_States_Census)|other races]], and 3.80% from two or more races. [[LINK|lang_en|Hispanic_(U.S._Census)|Hispanic]] or [[LINK|lang_en|Latino_(U.S._Census)|Latino]] of any race were 4.70% of the population. [[CITE|133|https://web.archive.org/web/20120529062726/http://censtats.census.gov/data/NJ/1603419390.pdf]] [[CITE|106|http://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/DEC/00_SF1/DP1/0600000US3401319390]]

There were 26,024 households out of which 31.9% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 26.0% were married couples living together, 28.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 38.2% were non-families.
33.0% of all households were made up of individuals and 11.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.

The average household size was 2.63 and the average family size was 3.37. [[CITE|133|https://web.archive.org/web/20120529062726/http://censtats.census.gov/data/NJ/1603419390.pdf]] [[CITE|106|http://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/DEC/00_SF1/DP1/0600000US3401319390]]
In the city the population was spread out with 28.1% under the age of 18, 9.8% from 18 to 24, 30.1% from 25 to 44, 20.8% from 45 to 64, and 11.2% who were 65 years of age or older.
The median age was 33 years.
For every 100 females there were 81.9 males.
For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 74.7 males.

[[CITE|133|https://web.archive.org/web/20120529062726/http://censtats.census.gov/data/NJ/1603419390.pdf]] [[CITE|106|http://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/DEC/00_SF1/DP1/0600000US3401319390]]
The median income for a household in the city was $32,346, and the median income for a family was $38,562.
Males had a median income of $31,905 versus $30,268 for females.

The [[LINK|lang_en|Per_capita_income|per capita income]] for the city was $16,488. About 15.9% of families and 19.2% of the population were below the poverty line, including 24.7% of those under age 18 and 14.0% of those ages 65 or over. [[CITE|133|https://web.archive.org/web/20120529062726/http://censtats.census.gov/data/NJ/1603419390.pdf]] [[CITE|106|http://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/DEC/00_SF1/DP1/0600000US3401319390]]

As part of the 2000 Census, 89.46% of East Orange's residents identified themselves as being [[LINK|lang_en|Black_people|Black]] or [[LINK|lang_en|African_American|African American]]. This was one of the highest percentages of African American and Caribbean American people in the United States Jamaica, Trinidad And Tobago, Guyana, Haiti and other smaller Caribbean Islands have a huge Caribbean presence, and the second-highest in New Jersey (behind [[LINK|lang_en|Lawnside,_New_Jersey|Lawnside]], at 93.6%) of all places with 1,000 or more residents identifying their ancestry. East Orange also has a large Haitian American community, with 2,852 persons claiming Haitian ancestry in the 2000 Census. [[CITE|110|http://state.nj.us/dca/home/2017mayors.pdf]]

Although still a small percentage of total residents, [[LINK|lang_en|Orange,_New_Jersey|Orange]] and East Orange have the largest concentrations of [[LINK|lang_en|Guyana|Guyanese Americans]] in the country. In the 2000 Census, 2.5% of East Orange residents identified as being of Guyanese ancestry. While Queens and [[LINK|lang_en|Brooklyn|Brooklyn]] had larger populations in terms of raw numbers, Orange (with 2.9%) and East Orange had the highest percentage of people of Guyanese ancestry of all places in the United States with at least 1,000 people identifying their ancestry. [[CITE|110|http://state.nj.us/dca/home/2017mayors.pdf]]
Economy

Portions of East Orange are part of an [[LINK|lang_en|Urban_Enterprise_Zone|Urban Enterprise Zone]] that was one of seven established by legislation in 1996. In addition to other benefits to encourage employment within the Zone, shoppers can take advantage of a reduced 3½% [[LINK|lang_en|Sales_tax|sales tax]] rate (versus the 7% rate charged statewide) at eligible merchants. [[CITE|110|http://state.nj.us/dca/home/2017mayors.pdf]]
Government

East Orange is governed under the [[LINK|lang_en|City_(New_Jersey)|City]] form of New Jersey municipal government. The government consists of a mayor and a city council made up of ten members, two representing each of the city's five geographic political subdivisions called [[LINK|lang_en|Ward_(electoral_subdivision)|wards]]. The mayor is elected directly by the voters. The ten members of the city council are elected to four-year terms on a staggered basis, with one seat in each ward coming up for election every other year. [[CITE|-1|https://web.archive.org/web/20120426060636/http://www.eastorange-nj.gov/PDFFiles/PEOPWard%20Boundaries.pdf]]

The City Council performs the legislative functions of municipal government by enacting ordinances, resolutions or motions, and is responsible for review and adoption of the municipal budget that has been submitted by the mayor.
[[CITE|28|http://eastorange-nj.gov/157/Office-of-City-Council]]

As of 2017, the [[LINK|lang_en|Mayor|Mayor]] of East Orange is [[LINK|lang_en|Democratic_Party_(United_States)|Democrat]] [[LINK|lang_en|Lester_E._Taylor_III|Lester E. Taylor III]], whose term of office ends December 31, 2017. [[CITE|52|http://eastorange-nj.gov/216/Office-of-the-Mayor]] Members of the City Council are: [[CITE|28|http://eastorange-nj.gov/157/Office-of-City-Council]] [[CITE|110|http://state.nj.us/dca/home/2017mayors.pdf]] [[CITE|137|http://essex-countynj.org/county-directory]] [[CITE|138|http://essexclerk.com/Election/View/58]] [[CITE|139|http://essexclerk.com/Election/View/44]]

sentences.text: **1st Ward** : Christopher D. James (D, 2017) and Amy Lewis (D, 2019)
**2nd Ward** : Romal D. Bullock (D, 2017) and Jacquelyn E. Johnson (D, 2019)
**3rd Ward** : Ted R. Green (D, 2017) and Quilla E. Talmadge (D, 2019)
**4th Ward** : Tyshammie L. Cooper (D, 2017) and Casim L. Gomez (D, 2019)
**5th Ward** : Alicia Holman (D, 2017) and Mustafa Al-M. Brent (D, 2019)

items.text: The first African-American [[LINK|lang_en|Mayor_of_East_Orange,_New_Jersey|Mayor of East Orange, New Jersey]] was William S. Hart Sr., who was elected to two consecutive terms, serving in office from 1970 to 1978. [[CITE|176|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=459]] Hart Middle School was named after him.

caption.text: A pre-WWII apartment on South Munn Avenue in East Orange.

items.text: Federal, state and county representation

East Orange is located in the 10th Congressional District [[CITE|160|http://state.nj.us/state/elections/2012-congressional-districts/njcd-2011-plan-components-county-mcd.pdf]] and is part of New Jersey's 34th state legislative district.

[[CITE|195|http://njelections.org/2011-legislative-districts/towns-district.pdf#page=14]] [[CITE|134|http://lwvnj.org/images/CG/2017_CG.pdf#page=57]] [[CITE|176|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=459]]

[[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey's_10th_congressional_district|New Jersey's Tenth Congressional District]] is represented by [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Payne_Jr.|Donald Payne Jr.]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Democratic_Party_(United_States)|D]], [[LINK|lang_en|Newark,_New_Jersey|Newark]]). [[CITE|176|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=459]] New Jersey is represented in the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Senate|United States Senate]] by Democrats [[LINK|lang_en|Cory_Booker|Cory Booker]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Newark,_New_Jersey|Newark]], term ends 2021) [[CITE|176|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=459]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Bob_Menendez|Bob Menendez]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Paramus,_New_Jersey|Paramus]], 2019). [[CITE|176|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=459]] [[CITE|176|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=459]]

For the 2016–2017 session ([[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey_Senate,_2016–17_term|Senate]], [[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey_General_Assembly,_2016–17_term|General Assembly]]), the [[LINK|lang_en|34th_Legislative_District_(New_Jersey)|34th Legislative District]] of the [[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey_Legislature|New Jersey Legislature]] is represented in the [[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey_Senate|State Senate]] by [[LINK|lang_en|Nia_Gill|Nia Gill]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Democratic_Party_(United_States)|D]], [[LINK|lang_en|Montclair,_New_Jersey|Montclair]]) and in the [[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey_General_Assembly|General Assembly]] by [[LINK|lang_en|Thomas_P._Giblin|Thomas P. Giblin]] (D, Montclair) and [[LINK|lang_en|Sheila_Oliver|Sheila Oliver]] (D, ). [[CITE|176|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=459]] The [[LINK|lang_en|Governor_of_New_Jersey|Governor of New Jersey]] is [[LINK|lang_en|Chris_Christie|Chris Christie]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Republican_Party_(United_States)|R]], [[LINK|lang_en|Mendham_Township,_New_Jersey|Mendham Township]]). [[CITE|178|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=468]] The [[LINK|lang_en|Lieutenant_Governor_of_New_Jersey|Lieutenant Governor of New Jersey]] is [[LINK|lang_en|Kim_Guadagno|Kim Guadagno]] (R, [[LINK|lang_en|Monmouth_Beach,_New_Jersey|Monmouth Beach]]). [[CITE|178|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=468]]

[[LINK|lang_en|Essex_County,_New_Jersey|Essex County]] is governed by a directly-elected [[LINK|lang_en|County_executive|County Executive]], with legislative functions performed by the [[LINK|lang_en|Board_of_chosen_freeholders|Board of Chosen Freeholders]]. [[CITE|233|http://essexcountynj.org/general-information]] As of 2016, the County Executive is [[LINK|lang_en|Joseph_N._DiVincenzo,_Jr.|Joseph N. DiVincenzo, Jr.]] [[CITE|178|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=468]] The county's Board of Chosen Freeholders consists of nine members, four elected on an [[LINK|lang_en|At-large|at-large]] basis and one from each of five wards, who serve three-year terms of office on a concurrent basis, all of which end December 31, 2018. [[CITE|233|http://essexcountynj.org/general-information]] [[CITE|82|http://essexcountynj.org/county-directory]] [[CITE|178|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=468]] Essex County's Freeholders are Freeholder President Britnee N. Timberlake (District 3 –, Newark's West and Central Wards, [[LINK|lang_en|Orange,_New_Jersey|Orange]] and [[LINK|lang_en|South_Orange,_New_Jersey|South Orange]]; East Orange) [[CITE|178|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=468]] Freeholder Vice President Brendan W. Gill (at large; Montclair), [[CITE|178|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=468]] Rufus I. Johnson (at large; Newark), [[CITE|178|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=468]] Lebby C. Jones (at large; Irvington), [[CITE|178|http://eastorange-nj.gov/?page_id=468]] Patricia Sebold (at large; Livingston), [[CITE|88|http://freeholders.essexcountynj.org/site/index.php?section=ps]] Rolando Bobadilla (District 1 – Newark's North and East Wards, parts of Central and West Wards; Newark), [[CITE|127|http://freeholders.essexcountynj.org/site/index.php?section=rb11]] Wayne L. Richardson (District 2 – [[LINK|lang_en|Irvington,_New_Jersey|Irvington]], [[LINK|lang_en|Maplewood,_New_Jersey|Maplewood]] and Newark's South Ward and parts of West Ward; Newark), [[CITE|180|http://freeholders.essexcountynj.org/site/index.php?section=wr]] Leonard M. Luciano (District 4 – [[LINK|lang_en|Caldwell,_New_Jersey|Caldwell]], [[LINK|lang_en|Cedar_Grove,_New_Jersey|Cedar Grove]], [[LINK|lang_en|Essex_Fells,_New_Jersey|Essex Fells]], [[LINK|lang_en|Fairfield_Township,_Essex_County,_New_Jersey|Fairfield]], [[LINK|lang_en|Livingston,_New_Jersey|Livingston]], [[LINK|lang_en|Millburn,_New_Jersey|Millburn]], [[LINK|lang_en|North_Caldwell,_New_Jersey|North Caldwell]], [[LINK|lang_en|Roseland,_New_Jersey|Roseland]], [[LINK|lang_en|Verona,_New_Jersey|Verona]], [[LINK|lang_en|West_Caldwell,_New_Jersey|West Caldwell]] and [[LINK|lang_en|West_Orange,_New_Jersey|West Orange]]; West Caldwell), [[CITE|225|http://freeholders.essexcountynj.org/site/index.php?section=ll]] and Cynthia D. Toro (District 5 – [[LINK|lang_en|Belleville,_New_Jersey|Belleville]], [[LINK|lang_en|Bloomfield,_New_Jersey|Bloomfield]], [[LINK|lang_en|Glen_Ridge,_New_Jersey|Glen Ridge]], [[LINK|lang_en|Montclair,_New_Jersey|Montclair]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Nutley,_New_Jersey|Nutley]]; Bloomfield). [[CITE|15|http://freeholders.essexcountynj.org/site/index.php?section=cdt]] [[CITE|83|http://freeholders.essexcountynj.org/site/index.php?section=districts]] Constitutional elected countywide are County Clerk Christopher J. Durkin (West Caldwell, 2020), [[CITE|115|http://essexclerk.com/About]] Sheriff Armando B. Fontoura (Fairfield, 2018) [[CITE|148|http://essexsheriff.com/sheriff]] and Surrogate Theodore N. Stephens II (2016). [[CITE|212|http://essexsurrogate.com/index.php/meet-surrogate-stephens]] [[CITE|82|http://essexcountynj.org/county-directory]]
Politics

As of March 23, 2011, there were a total of 36,280 registered voters in East Orange, of which 21,646 (59.7%) were registered as [[LINK|lang_en|Democratic_Party_(United_States)|Democrats]], 396 (1.1%) were registered as [[LINK|lang_en|Republican_Party_(United_States)|Republicans]] and 14,228 (39.2%) were registered as [[LINK|lang_en|Unaffiliated_(New_Jersey)|Unaffiliated]]. There were 10 voters registered to other parties.

In the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_election_in_New_Jersey,_2012|2012 presidential election]], Democrat [[LINK|lang_en|Barack_Obama|Barack Obama]] received 98.5% of the vote (24,862 cast), ahead of Republican [[LINK|lang_en|Mitt_Romney|Mitt Romney]] with 1.3% (330 votes), and other candidates with 0.2% (46 votes), among the 25,375 ballots cast by the city's 39,668 registered voters (137 ballots were [[LINK|lang_en|Spoilt_vote|spoiled]]), for a turnout of 64.0%. [[CITE|228|http://state.nj.us/state/elections/2012-results/2012-presidential-essex.pdf]] [[CITE|231|http://state.nj.us/state/elections/2012-results/2012-ballotscast-essex.pdf]] In the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_election_in_New_Jersey,_2008|2008 presidential election]], Democrat Barack Obama received 97.7% of the vote (24,718 cast), ahead of Republican [[LINK|lang_en|John_McCain|John McCain]] with 1.6% (408 votes) and other candidates with 0.1% (35 votes), among the 25,304 ballots cast by the city's 36,891 registered voters, for a turnout of 68.6%. In the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_election_in_New_Jersey,_2004|2004 presidential election]], Democrat [[LINK|lang_en|John_Kerry|John Kerry]] received 93.2% of the vote (19,447 ballots cast), outpolling Republican [[LINK|lang_en|George_W._Bush|George W. Bush]] with 5.9% (1,225 votes) and other candidates with 0.4% (128 votes), among the 20,856 ballots cast by the city's 33,328 registered voters, for a turnout percentage of 62.6.

In the [[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey_gubernatorial_election,_2013|2013 gubernatorial election]], Democrat [[LINK|lang_en|Barbara_Buono|Barbara Buono]] received 88.0% of the vote (9,413 cast), ahead of Republican [[LINK|lang_en|Chris_Christie|Chris Christie]] with 11.3% (1,212 votes), and other candidates with 0.7% (75 votes), among the 11,269 ballots cast by the city's 41,016 registered voters (569 ballots were spoiled), for a turnout of 27.5%. [[CITE|241|http://state.nj.us/state/elections/2013-results/2013-general-election-results-governor-essex.pdf]] [[CITE|243|http://state.nj.us/state/elections/2013-results/2013-general-election-ballotscast-essex.pdf]] In the [[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey_gubernatorial_election,_2009|2009 gubernatorial election]], Democrat [[LINK|lang_en|Jon_Corzine|Jon Corzine]] received 94.4% of the vote (12,554 ballots cast), ahead of Republican Chris Christie with 2.9% (380 votes), Independent [[LINK|lang_en|Chris_Daggett|Chris Daggett]] with 1.2% (153 votes) and other candidates with 0.5% (63 votes), among the 13,295 ballots cast by the city's 36,157 registered voters, yielding a 36.8% turnout.
Education

[[LINK|lang_en|East_Orange_School_District|East Orange School District]] operates the public schools of East Orange. The district is one of 31 [[LINK|lang_en|Abbott_district|Abbott districts]] statewide, which are now referred to as "SDA Districts" based on the requirement for the state to cover all costs for school building and renovation projects in these districts under the supervision of the [[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey_Schools_Development_Authority|New Jersey Schools Development Authority]]. [[CITE|67|https://njsda.gov/njsda/Schools/Capital_Plan.html]]

As of the 2011-12 school year, the district's 20 schools had an enrollment of 9,709 students and 867.0 classroom teachers (on an [[LINK|lang_en|Full-time_equivalent|FTE]] basis), for a [[LINK|lang_en|Student–teacher_ratio|student–teacher ratio]] of 11.20:1. [[CITE|2|http://nces.ed.gov/ccd/districtsearch/district_detail.asp?DistrictID=3404230&ID2=3404230&Search=2&details=1]] Schools in the district (with 2011-12 enrollment data from the [[LINK|lang_en|National_Center_for_Education_Statistics|National Center for Education Statistics]] [[CITE|4|http://nces.ed.gov/ccd/schoolsearch/school_list.asp?DistrictID=3404230&Search=1]]) are Althea Gibson Early Childhood Academy [[CITE|6|http://gibson.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (171 students; in grades PreK and K), Wahlstrom Early Childhood Center [[CITE|9|http://wahlstrom.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (167; PreK-K), Benjamin Banneker Academy [[CITE|12|http://banneker.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (491; PreK-5), Edward T. Bowser Sr. School of Excellence [[CITE|17|http://bowser.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (719; PreK-5), George Washington Carver Institute of Science and Technology [[CITE|19|http://carver.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (417; PreK-5), Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. Academy [[CITE|21|http://cochran.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (254; K-5), Mildred Barry Garvin School [[CITE|23|http://garvin.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (350; PreK-5), Whitney E. Houston Academy of Creative & Performing Arts [[CITE|27|http://houston.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (436; PreK-8), Langston Hughes Elementary School [[CITE|31|http://hughes.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (562; PreK-5), J. Garfield Jackson Sr. Academy [[CITE|34|http://jackson.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (288; K-5), Ecole Touissant Louverture [[CITE|37|http://louverture.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (309; PreK-5), Gordon Parks Academy School of Radio, Animation, Film and Television [[CITE|40|http://parks.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (313; PreK-5), Cicely L. Tyson Community Elementary School [[CITE|42|http://tysonel.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (509; PreK-5), Dionne Warwick Institute of Economics and Entrepreneurship [[CITE|48|http://warwick.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (453; PreK-5), Patrick F. Healy Middle School [[CITE|51|http://healy.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (420; 6), John L. Costley Middle School [[CITE|53|http://costley.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (453; 7), Sojourner Truth Middle School [[CITE|56|http://truth.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (459; 8), [[LINK|lang_en|Cicely_Tyson_School_of_Performing_and_Fine_Arts|Cicely Tyson School of Performing and Fine Arts]] [[CITE|60|http://tysonse.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (863; 6-12), [[LINK|lang_en|East_Orange_Campus_High_School|East Orange Campus High School]] [[CITE|61|http://eochs.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] located on the former campus of [[LINK|lang_en|Upsala_College|Upsala College]] (1,876; 9-12), [[LINK|lang_en|East_Orange_STEM_Academy|East Orange STEM Academy]] [[CITE|64|http://eoc9.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (199; 9-12), Fresh Start Academy Middle School – Glenwood Campus [[CITE|70|http://glenwood.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (6-8) and Fresh Start Academy High – Edmonson Alternative [[CITE|74|http://edmonson.eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] (9-12). [[CITE|78|http://www.eastorange.k12.nj.us/index.cfm?pID=11130]] [[CITE|85|http://eastorange.schoolfusion.us]] [[CITE|57|https://homeroom5.doe.state.nj.us/directory/school.php?district=1210&source=01]]

East Orange Community Charter School is a public [[LINK|lang_en|Charter_school|charter school]] that operates independently of the school district under a charter granted by the [[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey_Department_of_Education|New Jersey Department of Education]]. [[CITE|92|http://theeoccs.org/about/profile.jsp]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|East_Orange_Public_Library|East Orange Public Library]] at one time included three branch buildings of the original [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_Carnegie_libraries_in_New_Jersey|36 Carnegie-funded libraries in New Jersey]]. [[CITE|95|http://eopl.org/PR/meetEOPL.pdf]] It has a collection of 344,000 volumes and circulates about 319,000 items annually. [[CITE|211|http://php.app.com/census/results2.php?County=Essex&State=NJ&Submit=Search&Town=%25]] from four locations.

[[LINK|lang_en|Ahlus_Sunnah_School|Ahlus Sunnah School]] is a K-12 [[LINK|lang_en|Madrasah|madrasah]] that has been in East Orange since 2005. [[CITE|211|http://php.app.com/census/results2.php?County=Essex&State=NJ&Submit=Search&Town=%25]]
Transportation
Roads and highways
East Orange lies at the intersection of the [[LINK|lang_en|Garden_State_Parkway|Garden State Parkway]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Interstate_280_(New_Jersey)|Interstate 280]].

The Garden State Parkway passes through the city, connecting [[LINK|lang_en|Newark,_New_Jersey|Newark]] in the south to [[LINK|lang_en|Bloomfield,_New_Jersey|Bloomfield]] in the north. [[CITE|211|http://php.app.com/census/results2.php?County=Essex&State=NJ&Submit=Search&Town=%25]] The Parkway is accessible at Interchange 145 for Interstate 280 and at Interchange 147 for Springdale Avenue. [[CITE|211|http://php.app.com/census/results2.php?County=Essex&State=NJ&Submit=Search&Town=%25]]

As of May 2010, the city had a total of 83.43 miles (134.27 km) of roadways, of which 73.27 miles (117.92 km) were maintained by the municipality, 6.30 miles (10.14 km) by Essex County and 1.52 miles (2.45 km) by the [[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey_Department_of_Transportation|New Jersey Department of Transportation]] and 2.34 miles (3.77 km) by the [[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey_Turnpike_Authority|New Jersey Turnpike Authority]]. [[CITE|211|http://php.app.com/census/results2.php?County=Essex&State=NJ&Submit=Search&Town=%25]]
Public transportation

Local transportation around the city and into neighboring communities is provided by [[LINK|lang_en|Olympia_Trails|ONE Bus]] bus routes 24 & 44 and multiple [[LINK|lang_en|NJ_Transit|NJ Transit]] public bus lines, which includes routes [[LINK|lang_en|5_(New_Jersey_bus)|5]], [[LINK|lang_en|21_(New_Jersey_bus)|21]], [[LINK|lang_en|34_(New_Jersey_bus)|34]], [[LINK|lang_en|41_(New_Jersey_bus)|41]], [[LINK|lang_en|71_(New_Jersey_bus)|71]], [[LINK|lang_en|73_(New_Jersey_bus)|73]], [[LINK|lang_en|79_(New_Jersey_bus)|79]], [[LINK|lang_en|90_(New_Jersey_bus)|90]], [[LINK|lang_en|92_(New_Jersey_bus)|92]], [[LINK|lang_en|94_(New_Jersey_bus)|94]], and [[LINK|lang_en|97_(New_Jersey_bus)|97]]. [[CITE|211|http://php.app.com/census/results2.php?County=Essex&State=NJ&Submit=Search&Town=%25]]

New Jersey Transit also runs two [[LINK|lang_en|Commuter_rail|commuter rail]] train stations in East Orange, both located along the [[LINK|lang_en|Morris_&_Essex_Lines|Morris & Essex Lines]]. [[CITE|211|http://php.app.com/census/results2.php?County=Essex&State=NJ&Submit=Search&Town=%25]] The [[LINK|lang_en|East_Orange_(NJT_station)|East Orange Station]] is found beside the westbound lanes of Interstate 280, directly across its parking lot from East Orange City Hall. [[CITE|211|http://php.app.com/census/results2.php?County=Essex&State=NJ&Submit=Search&Town=%25]] Just one mile west up Main Street is [[LINK|lang_en|Brick_Church_(NJT_station)|Brick Church Station]], the city's second rail stop and the more heavily used of the two. [[CITE|211|http://php.app.com/census/results2.php?County=Essex&State=NJ&Submit=Search&Town=%25]] Both have seven-day service to [[LINK|lang_en|Hoboken_Terminal|Hoboken Terminal]] as well as [[LINK|lang_en|Kearny_Connection|Midtown Direct]] service to [[LINK|lang_en|Pennsylvania_Station_(New_York_City)|New York Penn Station]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Midtown_Manhattan|Midtown Manhattan]].

The city is 7.8 miles (12.6 km) from [[LINK|lang_en|Newark_Liberty_International_Airport|Newark Liberty International Airport]] in the nearby cities of [[LINK|lang_en|Newark,_New_Jersey|Newark]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Elizabeth,_New_Jersey|Elizabeth]].
